Posts.Content: Hello, I have IDC and was diagnosed in 2006, the most important questions I found were what stage is the cancer, (the lower the better), and has it spread, these are important questions to ask the Oncologist.  Make sure you get a Dr. you trust, trust is very important.  I am 47 yrs old and  I have stage II  Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (Adenomyoepithelioma) and received 6 rounds of chemo and 6 weeks of radiation.  My cancer was rare otherwise there wouldn't have been any chemo. I had a lumpectomy and went back to work in a week.  I had my chemos on Friday and was back at work on Monday.  With breast cancer a lot of people don't get sick or nauseous like they do with other cancers, I was a lucky one.  It wasn't nearly as bad as I thought that it would be.  Mainly I was tired and a little dopey, but hey I'm still here. I gained 35 pounds from the meds, lost my hair and eye brows and waddled for about a month from fluid retention.  But, the hair grew back (very nice), the eyebrows returned very bushy and the fluid went away.  I am now on Femara because I can't take Tamoxifen.  Just one pill at night and I don't worry about the cancer anymore.  I am still 35 pounds overweight but I am soooo going on a diet one day soon. I wish your mom all the best, and I will keep you both in my prayers.  kcmarrio
Posts.Title: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma

Posts.Content: On 8/7/2008 FindCureForCancer wrote: Hello everyone. I'm a new member here and I'm hoping someone out there can give me some hope and inspiration during this time. My 75 y/o mother was just diagnosed with IDC just yesterday and we're all just dealing with so many emotions! But fear is number 1. We're scared that my woderful, loving mother won't make it through the surgery. We're praying to God to give her the strength to fight this horrible disease. If there's anyone out there that had /has this and would like to offer some advice, I would really appreciate it. Thank you and may God Bless you and your families, Maria
Posts.Title: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma

Posts.Content: I feel your pain, literally.   I told my Oncologist that the joint pain from Aromasin was terrible so he gave me Femara to try.  Its been less than a week but the side effects seem to be about the same.  He told me if it got too bad that maybe he would put me on Remicade for the pain.  Its a shot in your butt once a month, but reading the side effects of that medicine makes me want to endure the pain. right now I am only taking oxycodone, and I can only take it when I go home from work because I handle needles all day long, and don't want to hurt any patients.  The Lyrica helped me gain 35 pounds so I stopped taking that.  If you come up with anything else let me know.
Posts.Title: Femara treatment

Posts.Content: I took Aromasin for three months and complained about the joint pain to my Dr.  He switched me to Femara which has the same side effects, but I have only been taking for a week now.  I do have a lot of pain, but am on my feet 10 hours a day at work, and am 35 pounds overwieght thanks to Lyrica,  but I hear that some people have little or NO pain.  Try it for yourself, don't let other people scare you off, everyone is different.
Posts.Title: positive feedback on aromasin

Posts.Content: I couldn't take the Aromasin, I did have the terrible joint pain that people told me about.  The up side is that I went on Femara and at first I had the joint pain, but after a month it seemed to disappear.  I just have a little pain once in a while now.  My nurse said that I didn't give it enough time.  I don't know, but the Femara is just fine.    Good luck!!!!!! Let me know how you do.
Posts.Title: positive feedback on aromasin

Posts.Content: On 9/7/2008 garden-800 wrote: I found out last week that I have cancer.  I'm so scared.  I worry about my soul.  I've been a smoker for many years and one of my biggest fears is that they will find cancer all through my body.  I also feal completely alone.  Oh my heavens, here you are never completely alone, there is usually  someone here to talk to.  Until you find out what kind of cancer and what stage it is, then no one can give you any help from personal experience.  Find out all the information that you can from your doctor and someone in here is sure to know something about it.  We are all here for different reasons, and for different cancers, and for different questions.  Hang in there it may not be as bad as you think.
Posts.Title: alone

Posts.Content: I couldn't take the Aromasin, I did have the terrible joint pain that people told me about.  The up side is that I went on Femara and at first I had the joint pain, but after a month it seemed to disappear.  I just have a little pain once in a while now.  My nurse said that I didn't give it enough time.  I don't know, but the Femara is just fine.    Good luck!!!!!! Let me know how you do.
Posts.Title: positive feedback on aromasin

Posts.Content: On 9/1/2008 kah49 wrote: I have had stage 2 breast cancer, (small tumor but it had spread to lymph nodes), also her2 positive. i have finished chemo and radiation and am now 5 months into the herceptin treatments. I also had double mastectomy. I would like to hear from someone who has been diagnosed as being her2 positive, and has had the herceptin treatments. I guess i would just like to know that there is hope at the end of this journey. My dr says that my cure rate is at about 70 to 80 percent, but I read that sometimes the herceptin does not always work. Even though my cure rate is pretty high, I still get nervous, after reading some of the info on breast cancer. Maybe I should just quit reading so much, huh? ha ha Thank you for any info k Hi I don't know how much help I can be, but I have stage II breast cancer, Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, not in the lymph nodes though, I am her2nue 3/3 positive, I am told that thats not to good, but my Oncologist says that I have an 80% chance or higher of beating this thing.  I have done the Herceptin for a year and had no side effects.  I have been off of it for 6 months now, and am now taking Femara to keep the estrogen away.  I haven't had a recurrance and don't expect to if I can keep up with the Femara (I had a bad reaction).  I think you'll be fine, and I'm sure that you are getting blood work every time you get the Herceptin, I'm sure they would have told you if they didn't think that the Herceptin was working.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: herceptin
